question.text: The genetic disorders in which the patients have one chromosome less than normal humans are:

solution.text: The presence of an extra chromosome in diploid chromosome number is called trisomy. It is represented by  <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>.</mo></math>  Here the patient has 47 chromosomes instead of 46. Trisomy of the 21st pair of chromosome- Down's syndrome. Trisomy of the 18th pair of chromosome- Edward's syndrome. Trisomy of the 13th pair of chromosome- Patau syndrome. Klinefelter's syndrome is due to presence of an extra X chromosome in males. The patient's cells contain one additional X chromosome along with XY. Thus their genotype is represented by  <math><mo>(</mo><mn>44</mn><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mo>)</mo></math>  and they have 47 chromosomes. The absence of a chromosome in diploid chromosome number is called monosomy. It is represented by  <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math> .Thus they have 45 chromosomes. Turner's syndrome is due to absence of one X chromosome in females. The patient's cells contain only one X chromosome instead of two. Thus their genotype is represented by  <math><mo>(</mo><mn>44</mn><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>)</mo></math> . Thalassemia is a disorder of genes and not whole chromosomes
